312 The digit 3 in the cell row 1 column 2 (i.e. r1c2).
{r1c1, r9c4}(13) The digit 1 and 3 in the cell r1c1 and r9c4.
13{r1c1, r9c3} The digit 1 and 3 in the cell r1c1 and r9c3.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Constants.Tables.RegionFirst
member.summary: Indicates the first cell offset for each region.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Constants.Tables.Peers

summary.para: Indicates a table for each cell's peers.

member.example: 'Peers[0]': the array of peers for the cell 0 (row 1 column 1).

member.name: F:Sudoku.Constants.Tables.RegionCells

summary.para:
The map of all cell offsets in its specified region. The indices is between 0 and 26, where:
0..9 Block 1 to 9.
9..18 Row 1 to 9.
18..27 Column 1 to 9.

member.example: 'RegionTable[0]': all cell offsets in the region 0 (block 1).

member.name: F:Sudoku.Constants.Tables.RegionMaps
member.summary: Indicates all grid maps that a grid contains.
member.example: 'RegionMaps[0]': The map containing all cells in the block 1.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Constants.Tables.PeerMaps
member.summary: Indicates the peer maps using table.

summary.para:
Indicates all maps that forms the each intersection. The pattern will be like:
.-------.-------.-------. | C C C | A A A | A A A | | B B B | . . . | . . . | | B B B | . . . | . . . | '-------'-------'-------'
In addition, in this data structure, a CoverSet is a block and a BaseSet is a line.
The table of all blocks to iterate for each blocks.
This field is only used for providing the data for another field .

member.summary: Indicates the map of possible positions of the existence of the candidate value for each digit. The return value will be an array of 9 elements, which stands for the statuses of 9 digits.

summary.para: Indicates the map of possible positions of the existence of each digit. The return value will be an array of 9 elements, which stands for the statuses of 9 digits.
Different with , this property contains all givens, modifiables and empty cells only if it contains the digit in the mask.
Indicates the map of possible positions of the existence of that value of each digit. The return value will be an array of 9 elements, which stands for the statuses of 9 digits.
Different with , the value only contains the given or modifiable cells whose mask contain the set bit of that digit.

member.returns:
The value that the cell filled with. The possible values are:
-2 The status of the specified cell is .

0 to 8

member.name: M:Sudoku.Data.Abstractions.IGrid`1.Exists(System.Int32)
member.summary: Indicates whether the current grid contains the specified candidate offset.
member.returns:
The method will return a ? value (contains three possible cases: , and ). All values corresponding to the cases are below:
The cell that the candidate specified is an empty cell and contains the specified digit that the candidate specified.
The cell that the candidate specified is an empty cell but doesn't contain the specified digit that the candidate specified.
The cell that the candidate specified is not an empty cell that the candidate specified.
member.remarks: Note that the method will return a ?, so you should use the code 'grid.Exists(candidate) is true' or 'grid.Exists(candidate) == true' to decide whether a condition is true.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Data.Abstractions.IGrid`1.Exists(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Indicates whether the current grid contains the digit in the specified cell.
member.returns:
The method will return a ? value (contains three possible cases: , and ). All values corresponding to the cases are below:
The cell is an empty cell and contains the specified digit.
The cell is an empty cell but doesn't contain the specified digit.
The cell is not an empty cell.

remarks.para: Note that the method will return a ?, so you should use the code 'grid.Exists(cell, digit) is true' or 'grid.Exists(cell, digit) == true' to decide whether a condition is true.
In addition, because the type is ? rather than , the result case will be more precisely than the indexer , which is the main difference between this method and that indexer.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Data.Abstractions.IGrid`1.GetMask(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get a mask at the specified cell.
member.param: The cell offset you want to get.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Data.Abstractions.IGrid`1.GetCandidates(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the candidate mask part of the specified cell.
member.param: The cell offset you want to get.

returns.para:
The candidate mask. The return value is a 9-bit value, where each bit will be:
0 The cell doesn't contain the possibility of the digit.
1 The cell contains the possibility of the digit.
For example, if the result mask is 266 (i.e. 0b100_001_010 in binary), the value will indicate the cell contains the digit 2, 4 and 9.

member.summary: Indicates the mask of block that all cells in this collection spanned.

member.summary: Indicates the mask of row that all cells in this collection spanned.

member.summary: Indicates the mask of column that all cells in this collection spanned.
member.remarks: For example, if the cells are { 0, 1, 27, 28 }, all spanned columns are 0 and 1, so the return mask is 0b000000011 (i.e. 3).

member.name: P:Sudoku.Data.Cells.CoveredLine
member.summary: Indicates the covered line.
member.remarks: When the covered region can't be found, it'll return (i.e. 32) always.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Data.Cells.CoveredRegions
member.summary: Indicates all regions covered. This property is used to check all regions that all cells of this instance covered. For example, if the cells are { 0, 1 }, the property will return the region 0 (block 1) and region 9 (row 1); however, if cells spanned two regions or more (e.g. cells { 0, 1, 27 }), this property won't contain any regions.
member.remarks: The return value will be an value indicating each regions. Bits set 1 are covered regions.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Data.Cells.Regions
member.summary: All regions that the map spanned. This property is used to check all regions that all cells of this instance spanned. For example, if the cells are { 0, 1 }, the property will return the region 0 (block 1), region 9 (row 1), region 18 (column 1) and the region 19 (column 2).

member.name: T:Sudoku.Data.Conclusion
member.summary: Encapsulates a conclusion representation while solving in logic.
member.param:
Indicates the mask that holds the information for the cell, digit and the conclusion type. The bits distribution is like:
16 8 0 |-------|-------| | |---------| |/////| used |
member.remarks: Two s can be compared with each other. If one of those two is an elimination (i.e. holds the value as the type), the instance will be greater; if those two hold same conclusion type, but one of those two holds the global index of the candidate position is greater, it is greater.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Data.Grid._values
member.summary: Indicates the inner array that stores the masks of the sudoku grid, which stores the in-time sudoku grid inner information.
member.remarks:
The field uses the mask table of length 81 to indicate the status and all possible candidates holding for each cell. Each mask uses a value, but only uses 11 of 16 bits.
|xxx|--|--------| |-------|-------| 16 8 0
Here the first-nine bits indicate whether the digit 1-9 is possible candidate in the current cell respectively, and the higher 3 bits indicate the cell status. The possible cell status are:
Status name (Value corresponding to enumeration) Description
Empty cell (i.e. ) The cell is currently empty, and wait for being filled.
Modifiable cell (i.e. ) The cell is filled by a digit, but the digit isn't the given by the initial grid.
Given cell (i.e. ) The cell is filled by a digit, which is given by the initial grid and can't be modified.

summary.para: Indicates which regions are null regions.
A Null Region is a region whose hold cells are all empty cells.

The property returns an value as a mask that contains all possible regions. For example, if the row 5, column 5 and block 5 (1-9) are null regions, the property will return the result value, 000010000_000010000_000010000 as binary.

If the output is single line, the output will append the candidates value at the tail of the string in ':candidate list'. In addition, candidates will be represented as 'digit', 'row offset' and 'column offset' in order.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Data.GridParsingOption
member.summary: Represents a grid parsing type.

summary.para: Indicates the susser format, which means all grid values will be displayed in one line with empty cell character '0' or '.'.
For example:

Indicates the shorten susser format, which means all grid values will be displayed in one line with empty cell character '0' or '.'. Different with the option , this option will continue shortening the code. The option will omit the continuous empty cells to a * in a single line. For example, the code
080630040200085009090000081000300800000020000006001000970000030400850007010094050
will be displayed as
08063*40,2*85009,09*81,*300800,*2*,006001*,97*30,40085*7,01*94050
via this option. We use the colon , to separate each line of 9 numbers, and then omit the most continuous empty cells to a *.
Indicates the pencil marked grid (PM grid), which means all grid candidates will be displayed using a table.
Indicates the table format, which means all grid values will be displayed using a table with empty cell character '0' or '.'.
Sudoku explainer format (9 characters in a row, and 9 rows).
Sukaku sudoku format (only contains the digits and the whitespace).
Sukaku single line format, which uses '0' to be a placeholder.
Excel sudoku format (only contains the digits and the tab character).
Open sudoku format.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Data.Node
member.summary: Defines a chain node, with basic information about the node. At the same time you can get the root node of the chain, using the current node as the tail node.
member.remarks:
The data structure uses an value to represent an instance. The bit usage details is as below:
| (4) | (3) | (2) | (1) | |-------|-------|-------|-------| 32 24 16 8 0
Where:
Part (1), bits 0..8 The mask of the digit used. The value only uses 4 bits.
Part (2), bits 8..16 The mask of the cell used. The value only uses 7 bits.
Part (3), bits 16..24
The mask of the on/off status indicating whether the node is currently on. The value only uses 1 bit.
Part (4), bits 24..32 The mask of the number of parent nodes stored. The value only uses 3 bits.
member.param: Indicates the mask that handles and stores the basic information of the current node.

member.remarks:
The data structure uses an value to represent an instance. The bit usage details is as below:
| (4) | (3) | (2) | (1) | |-------|-------|-------|-------| 32 24 16 8 0
Where:
Part (1), bits 0..8 The mask of the digit used. The value only uses 4 bits.
Part (2), bits 8..16 The mask of the cell used. The value only uses 7 bits.
Part (3), bits 16..24
The mask of the on/off status indicating whether the node is currently on. The value only uses 1 bit.
Part (4), bits 24..32 The mask of the number of parent nodes stored. The value only uses 3 bits.
member.param: Indicates the mask that handles and stores the basic information of the current node.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Data.Node.IsOn
member.summary: Indicates whether the node is at the on status.
member.remarks:
The possible statuses of the node are on and off, where:
Status Meaning
On
The digit is true in the cell, which means the digit should be filled in this cell.
Off
The digit is false in the cell, which means the digit should be eliminated from this cell.
